did.head: Summary Information
did.unittitle: Meier mss.
did.abstract: The Meier mss., 1927-2009, consists of the papers of Deborah W. Meier, the founder of the modern small schools movement.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Some files are closed to researchers.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Education reformer Deborah Meier (1931-) is frequently credited with founding the modern small schools movement in the United States. Meier was born on April 6, 1931 in New York City to Pearl Larner Willen and Joseph Willen. She had one brother, Paul Willen, born in 1928. Meier's father served as the vice-president of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies and her mother held positions in numerous organizations during her lifetime, including that of president of the National Council of Jewish Women. Deborah Meier grew up in New York City, where she attended the Ethical Culture Fieldston School. She began attending Antioch College in Yellow Springs, Ohio during the fall of 1949, but left before completing her degree to enter the University of Chicago in 1952, where she earned a master's degree in American History in 1955. She married Frederick Julius Meier on March 21, 1952, with whom she had three children. Beginning in the 1950s, Meier was also an active socialist, participating in the Young People's Socialist League and contributing articles to several socialist publications.

Deborah Meier began her career in education in 1963 as a kindergarten teacher in Chicago. In 1966 she returned to New York City, where she taught at PS 144 and was involved in open-corridor class experiments. In 1974, the superintendent of New York City's school district 4 invited Meier to create an alternative elementary school in East Harlem, a school which became Central Park East. This school was so successful that it was expanded into three schools: Central Park East I, Central Park East II, and River East. In 1985 Meier and the Central Park East staff again expanded the school, this time adding Central Park East Secondary School for students in 7th through 12th grade. Deborah Meier's work at Central Park East brought her recognition in the form of a MacArthur fellowship, which she received in 1987. Meier was the first public school teacher to win this award.

Meier began expanding her efforts in education reform as co-director of the Coalition Campus Schools Project, a position she held from 1992 to 1996. This project was an initiative to restructure large, failing high schools into multiple smaller schools. In addition, she was involved in New York City’s Annenberg Challenge and was a Senior Fellow at the Annenberg Institute at Brown University from 1995 to 1997. Meier was also involved in the Coalition of Essential Schools and the New York Network for School Renewal.
In 1997, Meier left New York City to found Mission Hill, a pilot elementary school in Boston. She served as Mission Hill's principal until 2005.

Meier has written numerous articles and several books on education, including The power of their ideas: Lessons for America from a small school in Harlem (1995), Will standards save public education? (2000), and In schools we trust: Creating communities of learning in an era of testing and standardization (2002). She also wrote Keeping school: Letters to families from principals of two small schools (2004) with Ted and Nancy Sizer and edited Many children left behind: How the No Child Left Behind Act is damaging our children and our schools (2004) with George Wood. Meier has received much recognition for her work, including honorary degrees from Harvard, Yale, Brown, and many other universities.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized into the following series: I. Biographical; II. Education; III. Correspondence; IV. Writings and speeches; V. Writings by others; VI. Professional activities; VII. Honors and awards; VIII. Politics; IX. Recordings and multimedia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Meier mss., 1927-2009, consists of the papers of Deborah Willen Meier (1931-), an education reformer and the founder of the modern small schools movement in the United States. The papers include schoolwork by Meier; personal, professional, and political correspondence; drafts and published copies of many of Meier's writings; writings by others on Meier and her projects; notes for speeches and final copies of speeches; planning documents for Meier's schools; school newsletters and mailings to parents; school booklets and brochures; student work; conference materials; awards; and recordings of Meier, student performances, and programs on education.

controlaccess.head: Indexing Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in IUCAT, the IU Libraries' online catalog. Materials about related topics, persons or places can be found by searching the catalog using these terms.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Many of Deborah Meier's writings can also be found on her web page: http://www.deborahmeier.com

userestrict.head: Usage Restrictions
userestrict.p: Prior arrangements are not necessary before coming to the Library; however, patrons from out of town are encouraged to communicate with the Library in advance of their visits to ascertain availability of materials.
Photocopying permitted only with the permission of the Curator of Manuscripts, Lilly Library
